Award.AwardTitle: MRI-R2 Acquisition of Enhanced Antenna Measurement Facilities for Emerging RF and Millimeter-Wave Applications

Division.LongName: Div Of Electrical, Commun & Cyber Sys

Award.AbstractNarration:
This award is funded under the American Recovery and Reinvestment Act of 2009 (Public Law 111-5).

Objective
The Antenna Research Laboratory at Villanova University is a unique regional and national facility existing in only a handful of US Universities. The existing facility is capable of automated antenna pattern, gain and radar measurements from 2 to 40 GHz, and has supported numerous projects in this frequency range. This 10-year-old facility, however, is rapidly becoming dated, and needs upgrading if it is to continue to be a useful means to conduct leading academic research and training. Our objective is to expand the
capability of this facility to include measurements from 500MHz to 110GHz.

Intellectual Merit
The intellectual merit of the new instrumentation is in expanding the performance of the existing facility to enable future leading edge research dealing with scale model measurements of antennas on large platforms, millimeter-wave antennas and arrays, Global Positioning Systems, wireless communication and RFID Systems, and Imaging Systems, all areas of interest to federal and industry sponsors and potential users of the facility.

Broader Impacts
The broader impact of the new facility is supporting innovations in antenna design across many engineering practices. The quantum leap in the antenna lab measurement capabilities will enable development of research and education activities in commercial communications, wireless receiver localization, RFID, and RF/millimeter-wave imaging. In addition to clear benefits to our graduate and research programs, we intend to design project modules relevant to the new facilities and incorporate them into the undergraduate curricula. We intend to utilize these modules in recruiting and broadening the participation of females and minorities in engineering research

POR.DRECONTENT:
This MRI-R2 project, awarded in 2010 and continued for three consecutive years, aimed at acquiring a range of antenna measurement instruments to upgrade and expand the old 2-40GHz measurement capabilities of the Villanova University’s Antenna Research Laboratory (ARL) in two directions: 1) upgrading of the compact-range facility to include millimeter-waves antenna measurement system up to 75GHz, 2) adding of a new near-field measurement system capable of accurate antenna gain and pattern tests at frequencies above 500MHz. These system upgrades were completed in 2012 and resulted in a comprehensive set of test capabilities for accurate antenna gain and pattern measurement from 500MHz to 75GHz (Figures 1 and 2) as well as radar imaging capabilities from 3GHz to 45GHz. These new capabilities of ARL have led to i) enhancing our ability to engage in both basic and applied research in emerging areas related to low-profile antennas, wireless communications, and radar systems, ii) establishing new opportunities for external research funding and sponsorship, iii) generating new means and projects for the involvement of undergraduate students in research and training, iv) creating valuable graduate theses and dissertations. In particular:

1. The new capabilities of ARL have already had tangible intellectual merits in advancing several areas of research dealing with scale-model measurements of antennas on large platforms, electrically small and ultra-wideband antennas, metamaterial antennas, through-the-wall imaging, urban sensing, wireless communications and RFID systems. Our research team, either directly or partly due to this MRI-R2 effort, has published 16 peer-reviewed journal articles, 34 peer-reviewed conference papers, and one book chapter over the last three years.

2. As a direct result of these enhanced lab capabilities, we have been successful in teaming up with various small companies and academic institutions in submitting three successful research proposals over the last two years.

3. We have trained one postdoctoral research fellow and three graduate students in antenna and radar research, resulting in one Ph.D. and two M.S. theses.

4. We have integrated the new test capabilities in lectures and associated laboratory demonstrations on antenna measurement techniques in one senior-level undergraduate and one graduate-level course.

5. We have showcased the new facilities to research, industrial, and business communities, as well as in recruiting of potential undergraduate and minority students through several outreach activities, which included:

i) Hosting six open houses for high-school students and their parents in 2010-2013.

ii) Hosting more than 50 middle school students and teachers from Brooklyn, NY through the Health Education and Enrichment in Arithmetic, Technology and Science (HE2ARTS) program in 2010. This is a collaborative science, technology, engineering and mathematics (STEM) enrichment program to service the Central Brooklyn region in New York City, with particular emphasis on schools with a significant minority student body.

iii) Hosting numerous visits by program mangers and engineers from federal laboratories, local large and small industrial companies, and academic institutions. These efforts resulted in writing of several joint research proposals as well as in the use of the upgraded facilities in joint research projects and publications.

iv) Hosting a visit by members of Delaware Valley Chamber of Commerce, Small Business Division, to showcase the new capabilities of upgraded antenna test facilities, and discuss potential for future collaborative proposal writing efforts between ARL and regional high-tech companies in areas of mutual interest.
